title: How to Create Sunlight in Studio with One Strobe
summary: Photographer Lindsay Adler demonstrates how to emulate the look of hard natural sunlight in a studio environment using a single bare bulb strobe. The tutorial covers set design, lighting positioning, camera settings, and post-processing techniques to achieve a high-key, sun-bathed aesthetic.

steps.action: Construct the set using a V-Flat placed directly behind the subject. Have the subject pose inside the V-Flat to create the illusion of a corner or location rather than a flat background.
Choose a strobe light with no modifier (bare bulb) to create a hard light source, which mimics the characteristics of direct sunlight.
Position the light source far away from the subject and raise it to a high angle. Increasing the distance makes the light source relatively smaller, resulting in harder shadows.
Set camera exposure settings to ensure a sharp image with deep depth of field.
Color grade the image to simulate the warmth of the sun. Warm up the white balance, increase contrast, pop the whites, and add yellow to the highlights.
Retouch the image to clean up the set. Remove V-Flat seams, extend the white background, and remove wrinkles from clothing.

key_takeaways: Sunlight is a hard light source; avoid softboxes and use bare bulbs or hard reflectors to emulate it.
The further a light source is from the subject, the smaller it becomes relative to the subject, creating harder light.
Posing a subject inside a V-Flat creates dimension and mimics a location corner better than a flat wall.
Post-processing color temperature is crucial to selling the 'sunlight' effect; adding warmth and yellow tones transforms a cold studio shot into a sunny scene.
